conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, we need to analyze both the p-T (pressure-temperature) and V-T (volume-temperature) graphs provided.
The p-T graph shows the relationship between pressure (p) and temperature (T). The graph is linear.
The graph indicates an ideal gas behavior where \( p \propto T \), or \( p = kT \), where \( k \) is a constant.
From the p-T graph: At \( T = 200 \, \text{K} \), \( p = 0.5 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \). At \( T = 400 \, \text{K} \), \( p = 1.0 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).

premise: From the p-T graph: At \( T = 200 \, \text{K} \), \( p = 0.5 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \). At \( T = 400 \, \text{K} \), \( p = 1.0 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \).
conclusion: We can use these points to find the constant \( k \): \( k = \frac{p}{T} = \frac{0.5 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}}{200 \, \text{K}} = 2500 \, \text{Pa/K} \).
The equation for the pressure as a function of temperature is: \( p = 2500T \).

premise: The equation for the pressure as a function of temperature is: \( p = 2500T \).
conclusion: Substitute \( T = 600 \, \text{K} \) into the equation: \( p = 2500 \times 600 \, \text{K} = 1500000 \, \text{Pa} \).

premise: Substitute \( T = 600 \, \text{K} \) into the equation: \( p = 2500 \times 600 \, \text{K} = 1500000 \, \text{Pa} \).
conclusion: The pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is: \( 1.5 \times 10^6 \, \text{Pa} \).
